text: <@U01FBLBCP7S> Tried plotting volume-integrated buoyancy and indeed it's not conserved (by ~40 ppm by t = 1 hour). Grows linearly but maybe that's because the plume keeps impinging on the immersed boundary.

elements.text: Tried plotting volume-integrated buoyancy and indeed it's not conserved (by ~40 ppm by t = 1 hour). Grows linearly but maybe that's because the plume keeps impinging on the immersed boundary.

text: Interesting.  I just realized I'm not entirely sure what the three different curves mean.  Is blue the physical domain and red the non-physical domain?

elements.text: Interesting.  I just realized I'm not entirely sure what the three different curves mean.  Is blue the physical domain and red the non-physical domain?

text: Yes. Blue (domain) is the buoyancy summed over the grid points of the physical domain of interest while red (immersed) is the buoyancy summed over grid points belonging to the immersed boundary. Green (total) is the sum of the two.

elements.text: Yes. Blue (domain) is the buoyancy summed over the grid points of the physical domain of interest while red (immersed) is the buoyancy summed over grid points belonging to the immersed boundary. Green (total) is the sum of the two.

text: Thanks.  So the good news is that the total buoyancy seems to be nearly conserved over the entire computational domain.  The bad news is that buoyancy seems to be leaked from the physical to non-physical domains. However, the relative chane is O(1e-5), which I presume means is a thousand of a precent?  If that's true then it's pretty small and might not be a concern.

elements.text: Thanks.  So the good news is that the total buoyancy seems to be nearly conserved over the entire computational domain.  The bad news is that buoyancy seems to be leaked from the physical to non-physical domains. However, the relative chane is O(1e-5), which I presume means is a thousand of a precent? text: I guess to answer that one could look at how well energy is concerved in the case of a vertical wall.  Is it on the same order as this?

elements.text: I guess to answer that one could look at how well energy is concerved in the case of a vertical wall.  Is it on the same order as this?

text: Ah you mean like put a wall using an immersed boundary and compare the conservation with the "rigid lid wall" vs. "immersed boundary wall"?

elements.text: Ah you mean like put a wall using an immersed boundary and compare the conservation with the "rigid lid wall" vs. "immersed boundary wall"?

text: energy won’t be conserved due to diffusion, either explicit or numerical in the case of non-second-order advection schemes

elements.text: energy won’t be conserved due to diffusion, either explicit or numerical in the case of non-second-order advection schemes

text: tracer conservation is a nice basic test I think

elements.text: tracer conservation is a nice basic test I think
